results.title: Electricity: a first film
results.creator_credit: BFA Educational Media and Norman Bean Films
results.brief_description: Shows how electricity works, how it is generated, and the ways in which it can be utilised. Also demonstrates principles involved in making electromagnets, and safety precautions with electricity. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: BFA Educational Media and Norman Bean Films

results.title: Electricity in agriculture
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Eric Thompson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows how to make the best use of electricity on the farm in Australian conditions. Commentator: John Morgan.

results.title: Electricity from chemicals
results.brief_description: Explains chemical reactions which produce electric current in a simplified electric cell. Discusses dry cell, nickel-cadmium and lead storage batteries. Introduces such terms as ion, charge and electrode. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description: Explains chemical reactions which produce electric current in a simplified electric cell. Discusses dry cell, nickel-cadmium and lead storage batteries. Introduces such terms as ion, charge and electrode. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Electricity and movement
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description: The basic principles of the electric motor. Opens with an account of the properties of magnets. Compares the action of permanent magnets and electro-magnets. An electro-magnet is used to work an electric bell. An electro-magnet is then adapted so that it turns on an axle and, in this way, the development of a simple electric motor is demonstrated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.description: The basic principles of the electric motor. Opens with an account of the properties of magnets. Compares the action of permanent magnets and electro-magnets. An electro-magnet is used to work an electric bell. An electro-magnet is then adapted so that it turns on an axle and, in this way, the development of a simple electric motor is demonstrated.

results.title: Electricity and light
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description: Explains how electrical energy is transformed into light by three methods - the filament lamp, the arc lamp, and the discharge tube. The film considers each type detail.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.description: Explains how electrical energy is transformed into light by three methods - the filament lamp, the arc lamp, and the discharge tube. The film considers each type detail.

results.title: Electricity and heat
results.creator_credit: Langton Gould-Marks, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description: The heating effect of an electric current is shown to be a clue to agitation of the aubital electrons; the difference between series and modern applications of electric heating are demonstrated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Langton Gould-Marks, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park

results.title: Electrical safety
results.brief_description: Presents five rules for using electricity safely and offers examples of the wrong ways of handling electricity based on these rules. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Electric power in Australia: 1968
results.brief_description: A comprehensive survey of power-plants all over Australia, showing thermal and hydro-electric systems and their relation to resources, industries and density of population

results.title: Electric furnaces
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare, British Iron and Steel Federation and Merton Park
results.brief_description: Steels for certain special purposes are made in furnaces heated by electricity. This film explains the construction and working of the electric arc and high frequency induction furnaces. Animated diagrams are used to illustrate the chemical reactions in the arc furnace and the principles of induction heating.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare, British Iron and Steel Federation and Merton Park
results.description: Steels for certain special purposes are made in furnaces heated by electricity.
